questions.text: A 72 y/o male, a k/c/o COPD presents to the ED with shortness of breath and confusion. He has been experiencing increased fatigue and worsening dyspnea over the past few days. O/E he has a respiratory rate of 30 bpm. Arterial blood gas analysis shows: PaO2: 58 mmHg, PaCO2: 52 mmHg and pH: 7.2. Which type of respiratory failure is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Type 1 Respiratory Failure

(Option A ruled out)

Type 2 Respiratory Failure

Definition

Hypoxemic respiratory failure

Hypercapnic respiratory failure

PaO2

PaO2 < 60 mmHg

May be normal or decreased

PaCO2

Normal or decreased

PaCO2 > 45 mmHg

pH

Typically normal

< 7.35 due to acidosis

A-a Gradient

Can be normal (low FiO₂/Patm, hypoventilation) or increased (V/Q mismatch, shunt, diffusion defect)

Variable, depending on hypoventilation or dead space

Primary Causes

  
  • V/Q mismatch
  • Diffusion defect
  • Right-to-left shunt
  • Low FiO₂/Patm
  • Hypoventilation
  • Respiratory pump failure
  • Decreased central drive
  • Neuromuscular impairment
  • Increased CO₂ production

Common Etiologies
  • ARDS
  • COPD
  • Congestive heart failure
  • High altitude
  • Pneumonia
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • AV malformation
  • CNS depression (e.g., sedatives)
  • Neuromuscular diseases (e.g., ALS)
  • Chest wall/pleural disorders (e.g., flail chest, kyphoscoliosis)

Respiratory Failure type

Definition

PaO2

PaCO2

Etiologies

Type 1 (Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure)

Low oxygen levels without elevated CO2

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 < 60 mmHg

- Alveolar hypoventilation (e.g., obesity hypoventilation)

- Low FiO2 (high altitudes)

- Diffusion defects (e.g., emphysema)

- V/Q mismatch (e.g., ARDS, COPD, pulmonary embolism)

- Right-to-left shunt (e.g., pneumonia)

Type 2 (Hypercapnic Respiratory Failure)

Inadequate ventilation with elevated CO2

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 > 60 mmHg

- CNS dysfunction (e.g., stroke, encephalopathy, ALS)

- Sedatives (e.g., opiates, alcohol)

- Chest wall abnormalities (e.g., kyphoscoliosis, obesity)

- Respiratory muscle dysfunction

- Ventilation issues (e.g., diaphragm dysfunction)

Type 3 (Peri-Operative Respiratory Failure)

Post-surgical respiratory failure related to impaired breathing

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 < 60 mmHg

- General anesthesia

- Supine position

- Depressed cough reflex

- Abdominal incisions

- Ascites

- Airway secretions

Type 4 (Shock with Hypoperfusion)

Respiratory failure due to shock-induced metabolic demand

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 > 60 mmHg

- High metabolic demand (e.g., septic shock, fever, exercise)

- Reduced cardiac output (e.g., cardiogenic, hypovolemic shock)

questions.text: A 65 y/o female undergoes elective hip replacement surgery. Postoperatively, she develops shortness of breath and a decreased oxygen saturation level. She reports significant pain at the surgical site and is reluctant to take deep breaths due to discomfort. O/E, her respiratory rate is elevated, and auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds at the bases. A chest X-ray shows areas of atelectasis. What type of respiratory failure is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Type 3 Respiratory Failure

(Postoperative)

Type 4 Respiratory Failure

(Shock-Related) (Option D ruled out)

Definition

Respiratory failure due to atelectasis from postoperative factors

Respiratory failure due to high metabolic demands from shock

Primary Cause

Atelectasis

Increased metabolic demands exceed respiratory capacity.

Mechanism

Alveolar collapse prevents oxygen from entering the bloodstream

The respiratory system cannot meet oxygen demands (e.g., sepsis, fever).

Common Etiologies
  • Pain post-surgery
  • Sedative use
  • Anesthesia effects
  • Sepsis
  • Fever
  • Cardiac events (e.g., heart attack)
  • Blood loss leading to shock

Management Strategy

Often involves supportive measures, pain management, Chest physiotherapy, Incentive spirometry, Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), Intubation and monitoring

Intubation for respiratory support and to reduce oxygen consumption during resuscitation.

Respiratory Failure type

Definition

PaO2

PaCO2

Etiologies

Type 1 (Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure)

Low oxygen levels without elevated CO2

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 < 60 mmHg

- Alveolar hypoventilation (e.g., obesity hypoventilation)

- Low FiO2 (high altitudes)

- Diffusion defects (e.g., emphysema)

- V/Q mismatch (e.g., ARDS, COPD, pulmonary embolism)

- Right-to-left shunt (e.g., pneumonia)

Type 2 (Hypercapnic Respiratory Failure)

Inadequate ventilation with elevated CO2

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 > 60 mmHg

- CNS dysfunction (e.g., stroke, encephalopathy, ALS)

- Sedatives (e.g., opiates, alcohol)

- Chest wall abnormalities (e.g., kyphoscoliosis, obesity)

- Respiratory muscle dysfunction

- Ventilation issues (e.g., diaphragm dysfunction)

Type 3 (Peri-Operative Respiratory Failure)

Post-surgical respiratory failure related to impaired breathing

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 < 60 mmHg

- General anesthesia

- Supine position

- Depressed cough reflex

- Abdominal incisions

- Ascites

- Airway secretions

Type 4 (Shock with Hypoperfusion)

Respiratory failure due to shock-induced metabolic demand

PaO2 < 50 mmHg

PaCO2 > 60 mmHg

- High metabolic demand (e.g., septic shock, fever, exercise)

- Reduced cardiac output (e.g., cardiogenic, hypovolemic shock)

questions.text: A 55 y/o male with h/o pneumonia is admitted to the hospital with severe shortness of breath. O/E, his oxygen saturation is 85%, and arterial blood gas analysis shows: PaO2: 55 mmHg PaCO2: 40 mmHg pH: 7.38 He is anxious and struggling to breathe. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient’s respiratory failure?

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen therapy via a nonrebreathing mask

questions.correct_answer: C. Oxygen therapy via a nonrebreathing mask
questions.explanation:
Respiratory Failure

Treatment

Type 1 Respiratory Failure (Hypoxemic)
  • Correct Hypoxemia: Aim to achieve PaO₂ ≥ 60 mmHg or SaO₂ 90-94%.
  • Oxygen Therapy: Use nasal cannula, face mask, nonrebreathing mask, or high-flow nasal cannula.
  • Avoid Oxygen Toxicity: Monitor to avoid excessive oxygen, which may lead to oxygen toxicity and CO₂ narcosis.
  • Refractory Cases: Consider extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) if hypoxemia persists despite conventional oxygen therapy.

Type 2 Respiratory Failure (Hypercapnic)
  • Correct Hypercapnia and Acidosis: Address the underlying cause and consider ventilatory support if needed.
  • Noninvasive Ventilation (NIV): Preferred for conditions like COPD exacerbation, cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and obesity hypoventilation syndrome. (Option B ruled out)
  • Ventilatory Support: Intubate and provide mechanical ventilation if severe, with goals to:
    • Correct hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis
    • Relieve ventilatory muscle fatigue
  • Mechanical Ventilation Indications: Apnea, respiratory rate >30, impaired consciousness, hemodynamic instability, or arterial pH < 7.25.

Type 3 Respiratory Failure
  • Pain management
  • Chest physiotherapy
  • Incentive spirometry
  • Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)
  • Intubation

Type 4 Respiratory Failure
  • Intubation for respiratory support
  • Reduce oxygen consumption during resuscitation

questions.text: A 30 y/o female presents with h/o wheezing and shortness of breath. A pulmonary function test shows a flow-volume loop with a distinct "scooped" appearance during expiration, particularly at lower lung volumes. Which condition does this flow-volume loop most likely represent?
Match the following diseases with their respective flow volume curves: 1. Asthma a) 2. Extrathoracic Obstruction b) 3. Fixed Obstruction c) 4. Restrictive Airway Disorders d)
questions.explanation:
Conditions

Flow Volume Loops

Normal (article)

A normal flow-volume loop displays airflow (in L/second) related to lung volume (in L) during maximal inspiration from residual volume (RV) and maximum expiration from total lung capacity (TLC).

Asthma (Airflow Obstruction):

  • Narrowed airways due to smooth muscle constriction and inflammation reduce expiratory airflow, causing a “scooped” appearance, especially at lower lung volumes.
  • Flow may improve after bronchodilator use.

Retrosternal Goiter (Extrathoracic Obstruction):

  • Extrathoracic airway narrowing can limit inspiratory flow, causing flattening of the inspiratory portion of the loop.

Intrathoracic Fixed Obstruction:

  • Fixed airway obstruction within the chest affects both inspiration and expiration, resulting in flattened, plateaued loops on both sides of the flow-volume curve.

Restrictive Airway Disorders (e.g., Pulmonary Fibrosis):

  • High lung recoil pressure increases expiratory flow for any given lung volume, producing a loop that is shifted to lower volumes and shows high maximal flow relative to volume.
  • Overall lung volumes (TLC, FRC) are reduced due to increased stiffness.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female patient presents with progressive shortness of breath and a persistent dry cough. She has a history of pulmonary fibrosis diagnosed two years ago. Spirometry shows reduced lung volumes. Which of the following is most likely true regarding this patient’s spirometry results?

options.label: A
options.text: FVC is likely to be increased.

options.label: C
options.text: TLC is likely normal or increased.

options.label: D
options.text: RV is likely normal or increased.

questions.explanation:
Parameter

Description

Normal Value

(Litres)

Tidal Volume (TV)

The volume of air inhaled or exhaled in one cycle

0.5 - 0.7 L

Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)

Additional air that can be forcibly inhaled after normal inhalation

1.5 - 3.0 L

Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV)

Additional air that can be forcibly exhaled after normal exhalation

1.0 - 1.5 L

Residual Volume (RV)

The volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum exhalation

1.0 - 1.5 L

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)

Maximum volume the lungs can hold (TV + IRV + ERV + RV)

4.5 - 6.0 L

Vital Capacity (VC)

Total air that can be exhaled after maximum inhalation (TV + IRV + ERV)

3.0 - 5.0 L

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

The volume of air remaining after normal exhalation (ERV + RV)

2.0 - 2.5 L

Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)

The volume of air forcefully exhaled in the first second of a forced expiration

3.0 - 4.0 L

Forced Vital Capacity (FVC)

Total amount of air exhaled during a forced expiration

3.5 - 5.0 L

Predicted Postoperative FEV1 (PPO FEV1)

Postoperative risk assessment parameter for thoracic surgery

Varies based on patient's condition

questions.text: A 45 y/o man with a history of COPD presents with shortness of breath, cough, and increased sputum production. His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows hypoxemia, and his calculated A-a gradient is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the elevated A-a gradient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type 1 Respiratory Failure Etiologies

Normal A-a gradient

Increased A-a gradient
  • Alveolar hypoventilation
  • Low atmospheric pressure/ Fracture of inspired oxygen
  • Diffusion defect: Impaired gas exchange leading to ↓PaO₂ due to thickened alveolar membrane. In emphysema and Interstitial Lung disease.
  • V/Q mismatch: Most common cause of Hypoxemia. Occurs when there is an imbalance between ventilation and perfusion. Examples - COPD, Asthma pulmonary embolism, ARDS, CHF
  • Right to left shunts - Blood bypasses the lungs without gas exchange.

questions.text: A 50 y/o male presents with worsening dyspnea. His pulmonary function test reveals a significant reduction in DLCO. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the low DLCO?
questions.explanation:
Diffusion Capacity of the Lung for Carbon Monoxide (DLCO)

The DLCO test measures how much CO moves from the alveoli into the red blood cells each minute. This test is vital because it shows how efficiently the lungs can transfer oxygen from the air we breathe into the bloodstream, making it an important tool for diagnosing and tracking various lung conditions.

Increased DLCO

Decreased DLCO

Increases with increased availability of surface area and haemoglobin in capillaries

Due to the thickened or destruction of the alveolar membrane and factors affecting vasculature.
  • Asthma
  • Polycythemia
  • Acute congestive heart failure (Option D ruled out)
  • Exercise
  • Obesity (Option B ruled out)
  • Pulmonary haemorrhage (Option A ruled out)
  • Altitude
  • Bronchodilator usage
  • Pulmonary fibrosis (Option C)
  • Emphysema
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Anaemia
  • COPD
  • Bronchiolitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Pleural effusion
